title.narrative: Inter-European Aviation Safety Program Management Course

description.narrative: This is a two-week course designed to provide students assigned to Flight Safety Officer (FSO) positions with a working knowledge of aviation mishap prevention. The course graduate is capable of administrating an aircraft mishap prevention program to include: Bird/wildlife aircraft strike hazard (BASH), midair collision avoidance (MACA), hazardous air traffic reports (HATRs), hazard reporting, inspections, airfield safety, Air Force Safety Automated System (AFSAS) queries, awards, disaster response, deployed safety, as well as philosophies and an understanding of the safety organizational hierarchy/philosophies. The course places Risk Management at the center of establishing a safety culture and addresses concepts, methodologies and best practices in the area of Risk Management, while providing how-to instruction in applying primary and select RM tools and techniques. IEASPM brings together aviation safety professionals from across NATO and PfP, standardizing tactics, techniques and procedures across the Alliance while building a common cadre of aviation safety professionals.

participating-org.narrative: U.S. Government - Department of the Air Force

title.narrative: Inter-European Aviation Safety Program Management Course

description.narrative: This is a two-week course designed to provide students assigned to Flight Safety Officer (FSO) positions with a working knowledge of aviation mishap prevention. The course graduate is capable of administrating an aircraft mishap prevention program to include: Bird/wildlife aircraft strike hazard (BASH), midair collision avoidance (MACA), hazardous air traffic reports (HATRs), hazard reporting, inspections, airfield safety, Air Force Safety Automated System (AFSAS) queries, awards, disaster response, deployed safety, as well as philosophies and an understanding of the safety organizational hierarchy/philosophies. The course places Risk Management at the center of establishing a safety culture and addresses concepts, methodologies and best practices in the area of Risk Management, while providing how-to instruction in applying primary and select RM tools and techniques. IEASPM brings together aviation safety professionals from across NATO and PfP, standardizing tactics, techniques and procedures across the Alliance while building a common cadre of aviation safety professionals.

description.narrative: This course is a modified version of the USAF Noncommissioned Officers Academy course which prepares NCOs for more advanced leadership and management responsibilities. It is the next level of PME designed for those assuming senior NCO leadership positions. Students learn time and stress management, concepts of human behavior, teambuilding, critical thinking, effective communication, and leadership techniques, as well as implementing quality in the workplace. Experiential course activities challenge each student to apply curriculum concepts successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. By virtue of its international student body, IENCOA fosters positive relationships between NATO and PfP members, as well as expanding students cultural knowledge and learning in a manner consistent with U.S. and NATO objectives. This course is delivered in parallel with the Inter-European Squadron Officer School to highlight the benefit of a professional officer and NCO corps relationship and develop an understanding of the importance of delegating authority and responsibility for operationally effective high-tempo aviation operations and support.

Experiential course activities challenge each student to apply curriculum concepts successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. description.narrative: This course is part one of a two-part requirement to be certified as a PME instructor. Part two consists of a 5-week Inter-European Officer Practicum Instructor Course (IE-OPIC) course, focused on practical application of principles learned in this course. The IE-OIC course consists of a two-week Theories and Principles of Adult Education (TPAE) course adapted from Squadron Officer College at Maxwell AFB, Alabama. TPAE prepares students to apply various instructional methods to deliver curriculum in adult education environments. Curriculum delivery is focused on achieving higher levels of learning through deliberate application of instructor skill sets. The course focuses on effective teaching techniques, including classroom management, feedback/assessment, and the integration of technology. Instructional methods taught in the course include lectures, guided discussions, case studies, gamification and experiential learning. All classes are developed using established educational theory, to which the students are also exposed. The course includes practical application and focuses on developing instructors through mentorship and actionable feedback. Graduates will be able to: apply effective techniques to accomplish learning objectives (alignment of course objectives, teaching, and assessment methods); apply effective communication and management skills inherent in a classroom environment; demonstrate various instructional delivery methods; differentiate between productive and nonproductive student behavior; assess student comprehension and application; apply appropriate motivational measures; analyze student learning and development; identify impromptu learning opportunities; and master integrated technology applications.

description.narrative: This course is a modified version of the program taught at the USAF Squadron Officer School at Maxwell AFB, which prepares junior officers for increased leadership responsibilities and is their next step on the Professional Military Education (PME) ladder. The curriculum is developed by the Squadron Officer College under USAF Air University guidelines, with minor adjustments for region and culture. Experiential course activities challenge each student to apply curriculum concepts successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. Graduates are equipped to better lead and motivate personnel, having practiced a variety of leadership, communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, teambuilding and mentoring techniques. IESOS is built around the following blocks of instruction: profession of arms, warfare, leadership, communication, and international security studies. By virtue of its international student body, IESOS fosters positive relationships with other NATO and PfP members, expanding students cultural knowledge in a manner consistent with U.S. and NATO objectives. This course is delivered in parallel with the Inter-European Noncommissioned Officer Academy course to highlight the benefit of a professional officer and NCO corps relationship and develop an understanding of the importance of delegating authority and responsibility for operationally effective high-tempo aviation operations and support.

description.narrative: This course is a modified version of the program taught at the USAF Squadron Officer School at Maxwell AFB, which prepares junior officers for increased leadership responsibilities and is their next step on the Professional Military Education (PME) ladder. The curriculum is developed by the Squadron Officer College under USAF Air University guidelines, with minor adjustments for region and culture. Experiential course activities challenge each student to apply curriculum concepts successfully and to influence group dynamics, cohesion, and effectiveness in a positive manner. Graduates are equipped to better lead and motivate personnel, having practiced a variety of leadership, communication, problem-solving, critical thinking, teambuilding and mentoring techniques. IESOS is built around the following blocks of instruction: profession of arms, warfare, leadership, communication, and international security studies. By virtue of its international student body, IESOS fosters positive relationships with other NATO and PfP members, expanding students cultural knowledge in a manner consistent with U.S. and NATO objectives. This course is delivered in parallel with the Inter-European Noncommissioned Officer Academy course to highlight the benefit of a professional officer and NCO corps relationship and develop an understanding of the importance of delegating authority and responsibility for operationally effective high-tempo aviation operations and support. Three in-residence sessions will be conducted in FY 2018.

title.narrative: Inter-European Tactical Combat Casualty Care Course

description.narrative: The course is primarily designed for combat Emergency Medical Service/military personnel, to include medics, corpsmen, and para-rescue personnel deploying in support of combat operations. The course is also applicable to non-medical military personnel and includes medical first responder skills appropriate for all military members likely to engage in direct combat. The course introduces evidence-based, life-saving techniques and strategies for providing trauma care on the battlefield.
